timeline.message:
Initial coding, not much here yet.  Commmit for backup (off my
machine) purposes.
GB Topology works, next: interface to existing editor

Intermediate push to see if my NetBeansOverrideFixGUI program puts
in @override statements that NetBeans improperly removes.

Added in TRL_Rules ability to comment on destination of rule.  Also
auto-generated this when auto-generating rules so user knows dest. of
rule.
GB Minor Maven cleanups
Missed a line to delete.  Test of Java line.
Fixed another Maven complaint
GB Another maven problem.
GB User documentation updated.  Not complete yet.

GB Moved my email system, I put a maven problem in to
see if I get the build failed email.
GB Fixed fake Maven problem.  Email received.

GB Final documentation updates, along with release notes for new
features.  Prior to WIP/PR.

timeline.bodyText: I'm not sure that it's good to add reference to the release notes here. That release note is only valid for the next major version and I guess it will then be removed from the release note.
timeline.author: danielb987
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,8 @@
 /**
  *  @author Gregory J. Bedlek Copyright (C) 2018, 2019
  * 
+ * Release notes(files): /JMRI/help/en/releasenotes/current-draft-note.shtml Section: CTC Tool section.

replies.bodyText:
Daniel:
(P.S. I sent this originally as part of a normal email, you may have gotten this already):
Thank you for the suggestion.  But the reason I put this comment line in there is so that I as a programmer can remember where in the huge directory structure the file is located, so that I can edit it.  It is only for "me".  At least if the name changes, the directory will probably still be the same.  So at least I have an idea where to look.  I'm not too good at remembering where 1000's of things are.  I'm only a lowly programmer shmuck! :-) :-)
Now that you understand why the comment is there (for my memory, nothing else), if you still think I should remove it, I will.  I tell you all this because maybe I don't understand your comment (because of my my lack of understanding JMRI in general).
And I really want to hear your opinion as to whether that is a good place for the memory aid for me.  I tend to put those reminders right in the source.  Maybe I shouldn't?  And I'm asking your opinion on that too please, not just this one.
Sincerely
Greg
replies.author: Gregory-J-Bedlek

replies.bodyText:
Daniel:
I talked at GREAT length to Dave Sand, and he explained to me why you said what you said.  I apologize.  I now realize that others will be looking at this, and they will think that it is something important, and not just a reminder for me.  I WILL remove it in my next push.  Sorry.
replies.author: Gregory-J-Bedlek

replies.bodyText:
Gregory:
Thanks! We are here to help you. Not long ago, I too was new to JMRI development so I know the difficulty with learning where everything is located in the JMRI project. There are still a lot of blind spots of JMRI development that I don't understand.
My suggestion is that you have your own document with useful notes, and that you keep that file outside the JMRI project. I have many such documents for things I'm working on.
Did you sent me an email? If so, to which email address? I haven't got any private email from you so my question is if there is a problem with my email? My email is db123 AT bergqvist.se, replace AT with @ . Feel free to email me if you want.
replies.author: danielb987

replies.bodyText:
Daniel:
Absolutely what I've done!  Thanks for your help in explaining further.
That comment is gone, and actually that "path" is in the JMRI documentation.
Web page: https://www.jmri.org/help/en/html/doc/Technical/gitdeveloper.shtml
Under "Develop and Test Locally", bottom paragraph.
That is good enough for me!
Sincerely
Greg
replies.author: Gregory-J-Bedlek

replies.bodyText: Don't worry about the email.  I realize now that I MUST reply within GitHub otherwise the email system eats it up I think.
replies.author: Gregory-J-Bedlek

timeline.message:
GB Put in skeleton test topology statements to allow CI to complete.
Will put in actual proper testing later.
GB Travis CI build stalled, try another attempt.

Problem with new version of CSVPrinter in Java libraries.  It seems it now adds
\r\n onto end of string when .toString() called on it.
I added code so that no matter what version of code Java libraries is,
it will now work.  Old version of CSVPrinter did not put on \r\n on
.toString(), verified.

GB Get rid of superfluous comments, and one minor bug fix whereby
SML from frog end of turnout doesn't get both paths.

GB Get rid of "programmer reminder" about where release notes
are (as comment in CTCMain.java) per Daniels suggestion.
Cleanup some more comments.

GB One bug fix "user can select in two different O.S. sections
the same locked turnout which causes a runtime stack overflow".
now the user is prevented from doing this.
GB Something put in a redundant import.  Removed.

Old habbit of putting in the return type which is automatically
generated by JavaDoc cleaned up hopefully everywhere in my code.

GB Added code to automatically fix file CTCSystem.xml when an additional
\r\n were introduced by CSVPrinter when the CTC Editor is run.  You
may immediately exit CTC Editor without saving, as the file has already
been fixed.  More code documentation too.

GB Finally learned how to configure CVSPrinter and CSVParser to not use
\r\n and also to quote ";" and "," separators properly, so that those
two characters can be included anywhere in the string data.
Also fixed a bug whereby there was a conflict between fleeting and
restricting signals.

GB A lot of code changes to support escaping "," and ";" in data.  Not
finished in the least.  Intermediate CI test to see if I'm on a wrong
track! (pun intended)

Revert "GB Finally learned how to configure CVSPrinter and CSVParser to not use"

This reverts commit c9e18652c54cb26440ec4ee6e5f8ca2ba913d43e.

GB Reverting.

Revert "GB Finally learned how to configure CVSPrinter and CSVParser to not use"

This reverts commit c9e18652c54cb26440ec4ee6e5f8ca2ba913d43e.

GB revert.
GB Revert

R
evert "GB A lot of code changes to support escaping "," and ";" in data.  Not"

This reverts commit 1f1e991737678a2545e30fc198da39569e7d3690.

GB Revert.

Revert "GB Finally learned how to configure CVSPrinter and CSVParser to not use"

This reverts commit c9e18652c54cb26440ec4ee6e5f8ca2ba913d43e.

GB Revert.

Revert "GB Finally learned how to configure CVSPrinter and CSVParser to not use \r\n and also to quote ";" and "," separators properly, so that those two characters can be included anywhere in the string data. Also fixed a bug whereby there was a conflict between fleeting and restricting signals."

This reverts commit c9e18652c54cb26440ec4ee6e5f8ca2ba913d43e.

Conflicts:
	java/src/jmri/jmrit/ctc/ctcserialdata/ProjectsCommonSubs.java
Hopefully reverted to proper state.
GB Travis crashed, just cause another CI

GB Maven crashed again, this time in other peoples code.  Try one more
tine.

GB Put up reminder message when first starting CTC Editor to tell
users that they cannot use ";" (semi-colon) and "," (comma) in
ANY System or User names that are needed by the CTC system.
Release notes and main CTC documentation updated with same also.

GB Maven failed, CPU busy timeout, try again.
Also: Partial coding of display to user of errors in separate screen.
GB Accidentally left some unfinished code in.

Support for displaying errors/warnings/info to user in case
System Console is not seen by user.  Preliminary code.
GB Spotbugs says use StringBuilder.

GB Replaced display of "," and ";" with a dialog box.
Finished displaying of messages to user should runtime encounter
anything.
Fixed a few "redundant imports"
GB Problem with Travis, timeout, try again.

New feature to warn users about usage of "," and ";" interfered
with automated testing procedure.  Needed to add another entry
to bypass this new feature during testing.
GB Fixed a test problem as exposed by new dialog.
